Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I was trimming Mrs. Lee’s fringe, the gentle hum of the salon soothing my nerves, when she glanced up and asked, “Could you just take a little more off the front?” She smiled, trusting, as always. I nodded, but my mind was elsewhere—my phone had buzzed twice already with urgent messages from the convent. The hurricane had devastated the town, and the mayor was pleading for help. As a nun, I was expected to drop everything, to lead the relief effort, to be a beacon of hope for those who’d lost everything. But here, scissors in hand, I was also a hairdresser, responsible for my clients’ comfort and satisfaction. Mrs. Lee deserved my full attention, her small request a reminder of the normalcy people craved. My heart pounded as I weighed the needs of my community against the promise I’d made to each person in my chair. The clock ticked, and I felt the pressure mounting, torn between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
